display.clozeText:
A _______ is a small part or quantity intended to show what the whole, or population,
is like.

A sample is a small part or quantity intended to show what the _______, or
population, is like.

A sample is meant to _______ the quality or style of the entity, or population,
from which it came.

A sample is meant to represent the quality or style of the entity, or _______,
from which it came.
The sample size is the number of _______ you took from your population.
The sample size is the number of observations you took from your _______.

When your study involves human subjects, your _______ is the group of people
who participated in the study.

When your study involves human subjects, your sample is the _______ of people
who participated in the study.

We use the term _______ to refer to how different, or how diverse, are the
data in your sample.

We use the term variability to refer to how _______, or how diverse, are the
data in your sample.
A _______ is one of many different ways we can describe traits of our sample.
A statistic is one of many different ways we can describe traits of our _______.

Examples of _______ are the mean, standard deviation, and variance; each term
has its own use (or several uses) in summarizing a set of observations.

Examples of statistics are the mean, standard deviation, and variance; each
term has its own use (or several uses) in summarizing a set of _______.
The statistical term for the "_______" is called the "mean."
The statistical term for the "average" is called the "_______."

The _______ is one number that represents a trait of the most typical member
in the sample.

The mean is one number that represents a trait of the most _______ member in
the sample.

When you _______ all the numbers in a set and then divide by the amount of
numbers you have, you get a statistic called the mean.

When you sum all the numbers in a set and then divide by the amount of numbers
you have, you get a statistic called the _______.
_______ and standard deviation are ways to conceptualize variability.
Variance and _______ are ways to conceptualize variability.

The term "difference from the mean" is the resulting number when you _______
a certain observation from the average of that sample.

The term "difference from the mean" is the resulting number when you subtract
a certain observation from the _______ of that sample.

We are studying weight. In order to calculate Bob's difference from the mean,
we subtract Bob's _______ weight from the average weight.

We are studying weight. In order to calculate Bob's difference from the mean,
we subtract Bob's observed weight from the _______ weight.

When you _______ the difference between one score and the mean score, you are
computing the variance for that measurement

When you square the difference between one score and the mean score, you are
computing the _______ for that measurement

When you sum the variance for the all of your measurements, you get the sum
of _______ from the mean in that sample.

When you sum the variance for the all of your measurements, you get the sum
of squared differences from the _______ in that sample.

In a typical sample, some observations are _______ the mean, and others are
above the mean.

In a typical sample, some observations are below the mean, and others are _______
the mean.

In calculating the variance for a sample, you must _______ the differences
from the mean before add them.

In calculating the variance for a sample, you must square the differences from
the mean before _______ them.

While calculating variance, one reason we add the _______ differences from
the mean, and not the actual differences, is that some of the latter type
will be positive, and others negative.

While calculating variance, one reason we add the squared differences from
the mean, and not the _______ differences, is that some of the latter type
will be positive, and others negative.

If you were to add the _______ differences from the mean, the positive and
negative numbers would cancel out and underestimate the variability of the
sample.

If you were to add the actual differences from the mean, the positive and negative
numbers would cancel out and _______ the variability of the sample.

The "sum of squared errors," which is often abbreviated to "sum of squares,"
is what happens when you add all the squared _______ from the mean.

The "sum of squared errors," which is often abbreviated to "sum of squares,"
is what happens when you add all the squared differences from the _______.

You get the _______ of a sample when you divide the sum of squared errors by
the number that is one fewer than the total number observations.

You get the variance of a sample when you divide the sum of squared errors
by the number that is one _______ than the total number observations.

If the sum of squared errors in a dataset is 100 and that dataset had 11 _______,
then you divide 100 by one less than 11, or 100/(11-1), or 100/10, or 10
to get the variance.

If the sum of squared errors in a dataset is 100 and that dataset had 11 observations,
then you divide 100 by one less than 11, or 100/(11-1), or 100/10, or 10
to get the _______.
The _______ of the variance is the standard deviation
The square root of the variance is the _______

One reason we do not typically work with variances is that, in _______ the
differences from the mean prior to adding them, we are now working with
a different metric from the observations.

One reason we do not typically work with variances is that, in squaring the
differences from the mean prior to adding them, we are now working with
a different _______ from the observations.

Squaring a value also changes the _______. For example, squaring something
measured in pounds will change the unit of measurement to "pounds squared."

Squaring a value also changes the metric. For example, squaring something measured
in pounds will change the unit of measurement to "pounds _______."

The variance is usually too big for descriptive purposes because it is the
_______ not of actual differences from the mean but of the squares of those
differences.

The variance is usually too big for descriptive purposes because it is the
sum not of actual differences from the mean but of the _______ of those
differences.

Taking the square root of the variance will _______ the value, thus undoing
the inflation that occurred when we added the squared differences.

Taking the square root of the variance will shrink the value, thus undoing
the _______ that occurred when we added the squared differences.

Taking the square root of the variance will revert the value back to the same
_______ as your observations.

Taking the square root of the variance will revert the value back to the same
metric as your _______.

A standard deviation can be thought of as one number that tells you, on average,
how far off the _______ observation is from the average of the sample.

A standard deviation can be thought of as one number that tells you, on _______,
how far off the typical observation is from the average of the sample.

response.correctResponse: std*.*dev.*~Yes - the answer is standard deviation;var~No - variance is actually the square of the stdev;.*~I have no idea what you meant by that

display.clozeText:
(Test NextLast/Stim0) _______ is a convenient way to discuss the typical difference from the sample
mean because it is in the same metric as the observations.

(Test Last/Stim1) _______ is a convenient way to discuss the typical difference from the sample
mean because it is in the same metric as the observations.
